Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research in Computational Biology at Mississippi State University
Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) award has been made to Mississippi State University that will provide research training for 10 students, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2013-2015. Undergraduate students will work on interdisciplinary research projects in computational biology. Students will work closely with their faculty mentors on projects in the areas of genome analysis, functional genomics, artificial intelligence, scientific visualization, and bioinformatics algorithms, among others. Recruitment will be targeted at colleges and universities within Mississippi and the surrounding states with the goal of providing a meaningful research experience to promising undergraduate students who otherwise would not have had the opportunity to engage in research. There is a particular focus on increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in computational biology research. Educational and professional development sessions will be conducted to train students in the basics of computational biology and to provide information on graduate school and pursuing scientific careers. Students will also receive training and mentoring in the responsible conduct of research. The program will culminate with a poster session where the students will present their research findings to the computational biology community at Mississippi State University. Program objectives will be assessed through the use of a common web-based assessment tool available to BIO-funded REU PIs. Students will be tracked to document their educational and professional path through periodic communication with students via email and social media. More information about this program can be obtained by contacting the project PI, Dr. Andy Perkins (perkins@cse.msstate.edu) at (662) 325-0004, or by visiting the project website at http://www.cse.msstate.edu/~compbio/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU site in computational biology at Mississippi State University has provided a ten week long mentored research experience for undergraduate students in the computational and life sciences during summers 2013-2016. Students have worked with faculty mentors and their lab members to perform research in bioinformatics and algorithms, genomics, visualization, population genetics, and others. Faculty mentors come from areas as diverse as computer science, biochemistry and molecular biology, biological sciences, animal and dairy science, and veterinary medicine. In total, 32 students received training in this program.

Students participating in the program received educational and professional development training in areas such as computational biology tools and techniques, responsible conduct of research, professionalism, scientific communication, and others. Students presented their work to fellow students, faculty, and the public at the Summer Undergraduate Research Symposium at Mississippi State University. Participants in the program have also been involved in a number of journal publications and presentations at professional meetings.

The program worked to provide research experiences to students from groups underrepresented in science and computing. 50% of participants were from groups underrepresented in computing and the sciences, and 38% of participants were from historically black colleges and universities. The program has also trained 69% of students early in their college career (defined as having just finished their freshman or sophomore year). The program also provides research experiences to students from primarily undergraduate institutions who may otherwise not have the opportunity to participate in research. 72% of participants came from institutions without a PhD program in the project’s area of study.

One of the goals of this program was to develop the next generation of scientists by encouraging students to pursue graduate studies in science and computing. While several of the program’s participants are still completing their undergraduate studies, 34% of participants went on to graduate studies, with several others taking jobs in science or technology.
